{{Infobox book | | name = Religion Explained: The Evolutionary Origins of Religious Thought | image = Religion Explained by Pascal Boyer book cover.jpg | caption = Cover | author = [[Pascal Boyer]] | country = | language = English | subjects = [[Evolutionary psychology of religion]]
[[Evolutionary origin of religions]] | publisher = [[Basic Books]] | pub_date = 2001 | media_type = Print | pages = 384 | isbn = 0-465-00696-5 | oclc= 50628396 }} '''''Religion Explained: The Evolutionary Origins of Religious Thought''''' is a 2001 book by [[Cognitive anthropology|cognitive anthropologist]] [[Pascal Boyer]], in which the author discusses the [[evolutionary psychology of religion]] and [[evolutionary origin of religions]]. ==Synopsis== Boyer describes the genesis of religious concepts as a phenomenon of the mind's [[cognitive]] [[inference]] systems, comparable to [[pareidolia]] and [[perceptions of religious imagery in natural phenomena]] resulting from [[face perception]] processes within the [[human brain]]. Boyer supports this naturalistic origin of religion with evidence from many specialized disciplines including [[biological anthropology]], [[cultural anthropology]], [[cognitive science]], [[linguistics]], [[evolutionary biology]], [[cognitive psychology]], [[evolutionary psychology]], [[neuroscience]], and [[information processing]]. ''Religion Explained'' frames religious practices and beliefs in terms of recent [[cognitive neuroscience]] research in the [[modularity of mind]]. This theory involves cognitive "modules" ("devices" or "subroutines") underlying inference systems and intuitions. For instance, Boyer suggests culturally-widespread beliefs in "supernatural agents" (e.g., gods, ancestors, spirits, and witches) result from [[agent detection]]: the intuitive modular process of assuming intervention by conscious agents, regardless of whether they are present. "When we see branches moving in a tree or when we hear an unexpected sound behind us, we immediately infer that some agent is the cause of this salient event. We can do that without any specific description of what the agent actually is."Boyer 2001:144, Boyer cites [[E. E. Evans-Pritchard]]'s classic [[Zande people|Zande]] story about a termite-infested roof collapsing.
For the anthropologist, the house caved in because of the termites. For the Zande, it was quite clear that witchcraft was involved. However, the Zande were also aware that the termites were the proximate cause of the incident. But what they wanted to know was why it happened at that particular time, when particular people were gathered in the house.Boyer, 2001:196, cf. 2001:12.
Within Boyer's hypothesis, religion is a "parasite" (or "[[spandrel (biology)|spandrel]]") offshoot from cognitive modules, comparable to the way the [[Reading (process)|reading]] process is parasitic upon [[language module]]s.
As I have pointed out repeatedly the building of religious concepts requires mental systems and capacities that are there anyway, religious concepts or not. Religious morality uses moral intuitions, religious notions of supernatural agents recruit our intuitions about agency in general, and so on. This is why I said that religious concepts are parasitic upon other mental capacities. Our capacities to play music, paint pictures or even make sense of printed ink-patterns on a page are also parasitic in this sense. This means that we can explain how people play music, paint pictures and learn to read by examining how mental capacities are recruited by these activities. The same goes for religion. Because the concepts require all sorts of specific human capacities (an intuitive psychology, a tendency to attend to some counterintuitive concepts, as well as various social mind adaptations), we can explain religion by describing how these various capacities get recruited, how they contribute to the features of religion that we find in so many different cultures. We do not need to assume that there is a special way of functioning that occurs only when processing religious thoughts.Boyer, 2001:311.
Boyer admits his explanation of religion
is ''not'' a quick, shoot-from-the-hip solution of the kind that many people, either religious or not, seem to favor. There cannot be a magic bullet to explain the existence and common features of religion, as the phenomenon is the result of ''aggregate relevance'' – that is, of successful activation of a whole variety of mental systems.Boyer 2001:298, italics in original.
==Reviews and criticisms== {{summarize section|date=January 2011}} Critical reception of ''Religion Explained'' has been mixed. [[Benjamin Beit-Hallahmi]], a professor of developmental psychology at the [[University of Haifa]], called the book "a milestone on the road to a new behavioral understanding of religion, basing itself on what has come to be known as cognitive anthropology, and pointedly ignoring much work done over the past one hundred years in the behavioral study of religion and in the psychological anthropology of religion."[http://www.human-nature.com/nibbs/02/boyer.html Book Review: Religion Explained] ''Human Nature Review'' 2002 Volume 2: 308–309 (22 July) He continues:
The clearest virtue of this book is that of dealing with the real thing. Even today, most scholarly work on religion consists of apologetics in one form or another, and we are deluged by offers of grants to study "spirituality" or teach "religion and science". This all serves to make us forget that religion is a collection of fantasies about spirits, and Boyer indeed aims to teach us about the world of the spirits in the grand tradition of the Enlightenment. Any general introduction to the world of the spirits must be ambitious because it hasn't been done and also because it has been done intuitively by all of us.
[[David Klinghoffer]], a journalist and [[intelligent design]] proponent, wrote in the ''[[National Review]]'' that "Boyer's talk of 'religion is suspiciously generic" and describes his work as "professorial noodlings" that attempt to raise the question whether "all religions are somehow the same". He further claims that "debunkers like Boyer ... have their own unconscious motivations (to undermine religious faith, after all, is to set oneself free of its many inconvenient strictures)."[https://web.archive.org/web/20080421220616/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1282/is_19_53/ai_78692094/pg_2 Faith no more—Religion Explained: The Evolutionary Origins of Religious Thought—Review] [[Michael Shermer]], founder of [[The Skeptics Society]], described Boyer's book as:
a penetratingly insightful scientific analysis of religion because as an anthropologist he understands that any explanation must take into account the rich diversity of religious practices and beliefs around the world, and as a scientist he knows that any explanatory model must account for this diversity. Boyer is at his ethnographic best in describing the countless peculiar religious rituals he and his anthropological brethren have recorded, and especially in identifying the shortcomings of virtually every explanation for religion ever offered. … As a consequence, however, Boyer himself fails to provide a satisfactory explanation because he knows that religion is not a single entity resulting from a single cause.Shermer, Michael. 2001. ''How We Believe: Science, Skepticism, and the Search for God'', 2nd ed., Macmillan, p 256.
Brigitte Schön, a theology professor at the [[University of Bonn]], wrote,
Apart from being fascinating to read and containing many more highly original ideas than could be mentioned here, ''Religion explained'' is an important book for a number of reasons. First of all, Boyer is able to present a very dense network of theories which not only explains many religious phenomena but also sets them in relation to each other. The integration of cognitive science research leads to a very realistic model of how religious concepts are processed and communicated, something which has been conspicuously absent from most theories of religion so far. Boyer's account of the natural basis of religion explains very well the persistence and re-emergence of religion even in a secularized environment, as well as the tensions between official and folk religion.Brigitte Schön. [http://www.uni-marburg.de/fb03/ivk/mjr/pdfs/2002/reviews/rev_schoen_2002.pdf "''Religion Explained: The evolutionary origins of religious thought''"], ''Marburg Journal of Religion'' 2002 7.1:1–3.
[[Garry Runciman, 3rd Viscount Runciman of Doxford|Garry Runciman]], sociologist at [[Trinity College, Cambridge]], asked "Are we hardwired for God?"
The diverse beliefs which Boyer cites extend from Apollo and Athena, to shamanism among the Panamanian Cuna, to aliens from remote galaxies allegedly landing in New Mexico. But his central agenda is the particular set of unobservable causal agencies cited in his subtitle, and his primary concern is with the question of how we are to account for beliefs that involve the attribution of conscious agency to beings other than humans and animals of the normal and familiar kind. Such beliefs are, as Boyer says, remarkably widespread, and for all their variant forms the variation is neither limitless nor random. His answer falls into two parts: first, these beliefs have in common a counterintuitive attribution of a certain range of properties to certain kinds of quasihuman being; second, the explanation of their diffusion and persistence is to be sought not in the extensive anthropological literature about the origins and functions of religion, but in recent advances in developmental, cognitive and evolutionary psychology.W.G. Runciman. [https://www.theguardian.com/books/2002/feb/07/londonreviewofbooks/print Are we hardwired for God?], ''London Review of Books'', July 2, 2002.
Author and economist [[Zachary Karabell]] found stylistic faults. "Boyer's use of cognitive psychology, anthropology and other disciplines does generate a new template for examining old questions. But his method, however compelling, does not save the book from its considerable flaws. To begin with, the writing is frequently impenetrable." He concludes, "Of course, Boyer may be right. Human existence may simply be a story of living, breathing, eating and dying. But by not grappling with the possibility that a nonmaterial realm exists, Boyer has written a book about religion that is occasionally illuminating and utterly unconvincing."Zachary Karabell. [http://www.rivertwice.com/articles/pdfs/A_True_Believer_%20in_Science_Offers_a_Lopsided_Look_LAT.pdf A True Believer in Science Offers a Lopsided Look at Faith; ''RELIGION EXPLAINED: The Evolutionary Origins of Religious Thought'', By Pascal Boyer] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715191026/http://www.rivertwice.com/articles/pdfs/A_True_Believer_%20in_Science_Offers_a_Lopsided_Look_LAT.pdf |date=2011-07-15 }}, ''Los Angeles Times'' June 16, 2001 The [[comparative religion]] author [[Karen Armstrong]] reviewed Boyer's thesis.
Religion, he argues, is nothing more or less than a by-product of the human mind. It is a side effect of having a particular kind of brain. By far the most fascinating part of this highly accessible and informative book is Boyer's description of the way our minds work. We have an inbuilt set of ontological expectations and a tendency to dwell on intuitions which violate these, such as mountains that float or companions whom we do not see. From the dawn of modern consciousness, men and women have focused on certain imaginary personalities that transcend the norm, convinced that they can help them in strategic ways. These supernatural agents link with other mental systems, such as our moral intuitions and social categories, for which we can find no conceptual justification.Karen Armstrong, [http://www.asa3.org/archive/asa/200109/0070.html ''Religion Explained'' by Pascal Boyer], ''The Times'', August 29, 2001
[[John Habgood, Baron Habgood|John Habgood]], formerly [[Archbishop of York]], wrote.
This is a bold and far-reaching book. What its author lacks in modesty, he makes up for in cogency of argument and elegance of style. His "explanation" of religion is lucid, entertaining, full of valuable insights and almost, but not quite, convincing. The usual explanations of religion—as an attempt to explain what is otherwise puzzling, as a provider of comfort, as a good thing for society or as an escape from reason—are quickly dismissed. Pascal Boyer seeks to demonstrate that its origins and motivations are more deep seated in our mental structures than any of these, which is why religion is so universal, so powerful and so unlikely to disappear even though, as he also claims, it is in the end only a mental phenomenon. Recent experience of the dreadful consequences of religious fanaticism gives his analysis a frightening contemporary relevance, not least because of the minor role within religion that he assigns to rationality.John Habgood, [http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=166258§ioncode=40 "Parasite of airy nothings?"], ''Times Higher Education'', 14 December 2001.
==Editions and translations== Boyer's book is available in several English versions, as well as French, German, Greek, Italian and Polish translations. Publishers have variously altered the ''Religion Explained'' title. The American edition was published as: *''Religion Explained: The Human Instincts That Fashion Gods, Spirits and Ancestors'', hardcover, Basic Books, 2001, {{ISBN|0-465-00695-7}}. *''Religion Explained: The Human Instincts That Fashion Gods, Spirits and Ancestors'', paperback, Vintage, 2002, {{ISBN|0-09-928276-3}}. *''Religion Explained'', paperback, Basic Books, 2002, {{ISBN|0-465-00696-5}}. The British edition, which changed the subtitle from "''The Evolutionary Origins of Religious Thought''" to "''The Human Instincts That Fashion Gods, Spirits and Ancestors''", was published as: *''Religion Explained: The Human Instincts That Fashion Gods, Spirits and Ancestors'', hardcover, William Heinemann Ltd, 2001, {{ISBN|0-465-00695-7}}. *''Religion Explained: The Human Instincts That Fashion Gods, Spirits and Ancestors'', paperback, Vintage, 2002, {{ISBN|0-09-928276-3}}. Translated editions of ''Religion Explained'' are available in several European languages: *French translation by Claude-Christine Farny as ''Et l'homme créa les dieux: Comment expliquer la religion'' [And Man Created the Gods: How to Explain Religion], Paris: Robert Laffont, 2001, {{ISBN|978-2-221-09046-6}}. *German translation by Ulrich Enderwitz, Monika Noll, and Rolf Schubert as ''Und Mensch schuf Gott'' [And Man Created God], Klett-Cotta, 2004, {{ISBN|978-3-608-94032-9}}. *Greek translation by Dimitris Xygalatas and Nikolas Roubekas as ''Και ο Άνθρωπος Έπλασε τους Θεούς'' [And Man Created the Gods], Thessaloniki: Vanias, 2008. {{ISBN|978-960-288-225-2}}.[http://www.protoporia.gr/product_info.php/products_id/308148 Πρωτοπορία] *Italian translation by Donatella Sutera Sardo as "E l'uomo creò gli dei. Come spiegare la religione" [And man created the Gods. How to Explain Religion], Bologna, Odoya, 2010 {{ISBN|978-88-6288-073-2}}. *Polish translation by Krystyna Szeżyńska-Maćkowiak as ''I człowiek stworzył bogów...'' [And man created the gods...], Warsaw, 2005, {{ISBN|83-7337-985-1}}. * Dutch translation by Leo Gillet as "Godsdienst verklaard", Amsterdam: De Bezige Bij, 2002 {{ISBN|90-234-7083-4}} . * Russian translation by Mariya Desyatova as "Объясняя религию. Природа религиозного мышления" [Religion Explained. Nature of religious thinking], Moscow: Alpina nonfiction, 2016 {{ISBN|978-5-91671-632-0}} . ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://metapsychology.mentalhelp.net/poc/view_doc.php?type=book&id=1466 Review – ''Religion Explained''], David Livingstone Smith, Metapsychology Online Reviews *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091205023359/http://naturalscience.com/ns/books/book14.html ''Religion Explained: The Evolutionary Origins of Religious Thought''], Jim Rossi, NaturalScience *[http://www.wordtrade.com/society/anthropologyreligion.htm Anthropology of Religion], Wordtrade.com Social Science *[http://www.complete-review.com/reviews/religion/boyerp.htm ''Religion Explained'' by Pascal Boyer], The Complete Review *[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/article1131051.ece God on the brain: is religion just a step away from mental illness?], [[Anjana Ahuja]], ''The Times'', April 17, 2003 [[Category:2001 books]] [[Category:Anthropology books]] [[Category:Basic Books books]] [[Category:Books about evolutionary psychology]] [[Category:Books critical of religion]] [[Category:Psychology of religion]] [[Category:Religious studies]]

[[Image:Rungholt in Germany.png|thumb|Likeliest locations of Rungholt]] [[Image:Strand i Valdemarernes Tid.png|thumb|Rungholt and Strand in the Middle Ages, on a map from 1850]] [[Image:Funde Rungholt.JPG|thumb|Finds from the Wadden Sea, possibly from Rungholt]]
'''Rungholt''' was a settlement in [[Nordfriesland]], in what was then the [[Denmark|Danish]] [[Duchy of Schleswig]]. The area is today located in [[Germany]]. Rungholt reportedly sank beneath the waves of the [[North Sea]] when a [[Storm tides of the North Sea|storm tide]] (known as the second ''[[Grote Mandrenke]]'') hit the coast on 15 or 16 January 1362.
==Location== The exact location of Rungholt remains unclear. It is likely that Rungholt was situated on the island of [[Strand (island)|Strand]], which was rent asunder by another storm tide in 1634, and of which the islets of [[Pellworm]], [[Nordstrand, Germany|Nordstrand]] and [[Nordstrandischmoor]] are the only remaining fragments.
One possible location is west of the Hallig [[Südfall]], where in 1921 significant ruins were discovered: wells, trenches and part of a tidal lock. Another theory places Rungholt to the north of the Hallig Südfall.<ref name="NDR">{{cite web|url=http://www.ndr.de/kultur/geschichte/chronologie/Rungholt-Atlantis-der-Nordsee,rungholt101.html|title=Rungholt – "Atlantis der Nordsee" (German)|publisher=Norddeutscher Rundfunk| date= 13 July 2012 |first=Levke|last=Heed|accessdate=15 June 2016}}</ref><ref name="Focus">{{cite web|url=http://www.focus.de/wissen/mensch/archaeologie/tid-26901/versunkene-staedte-2-rungholt-das-deutsche-atlantis_aid_798853.html|title=Rungholt – das deutsche Atlantis (German)|publisher=Focus Online| date= 15 August 2012 |first=Christina|last=Steinlein|accessdate=15 June 2016}}</ref><ref name="HN">{{cite web|url=http://www.shz.de/lokales/husumer-nachrichten/rungholt-auf-den-spuren-einer-versunkenen-welt-id7438356.html|title=Rungholt – auf den Spuren einer versunkenen Welt (German)|publisher=Husumer Nachrichten| date= 22 August 2014 |first=|last=|accessdate=15 June 2016}}</ref>
==History== Today it is widely accepted that Rungholt did in fact exist and was not just a local legend. Documents support this, although they mostly date from much later times (16th century). Archaeologists think Rungholt was an important town and port. It might have contained up to 500 houses, with about 3,000 people. Findings indicate trade in agricultural products and possibly [[amber]]. Supposed relics of the town have been found in the [[Wadden Sea]], but shifting sediments make it hard to preserve them.<ref name="NDR"/><ref name="Focus"/>
There definitely was a great storm known as the ''[[Grote Mandrenke]]'', and sometimes also named after the saint [[Pope Marcellus I|Marcellus]], on 15 or 16 January 1362.<ref name="NDR"/> Estimates put the number of deaths at around 10,000. Possibly 30 settlements were destroyed, and the coastline shifted east, leaving formerly inhabited land in the tidal Wadden Sea.<ref name="Focus"/><ref name="HN"/>
==Legends and later reception== Sometimes referred to as the "Atlantis of the North Sea", the Rungholt of legend was a large, rich town and the catastrophe supposedly a divine punishment for the sins of its inhabitants.<ref name="NDR"/>
Impressed by the fate of the town, the relics, and not least the legends' excessive descriptions, the German poet [[Detlev von Liliencron]] wrote a popular poem in 1882 called "''Trutz, Blanke Hans''" about this lost town which starts with the words: ''Heut bin ich über Rungholt gefahren, die Stadt ging unter vor sechshundert Jahren.'' ("Today I traveled over Rungholt; the town sank 600 years ago.").<ref>[https://de.wikisource.org/wiki/Trutz,_Blanke_Hans Trutz, Blanke Hans (Wikisource)]</ref>
German singer [[Achim Reichel]] put [[Detlev von Liliencron|Liliencron's]] poem to music on his 1977 album "Regenballade".
German metal band [[Santiano_(band)|Santiano]] released a song called Rungholt in their 2015 CD "Von Liebe, Tod und Freiheit". It also includes verses from von Liliencron's poem.
[[Theodor Storm]] also mentions Rungholt in his [[novella]] ''Eine Halligfahrt''.<ref name="NDR"/>
[[Christian Kracht]] mentions Rungholt in his [[novella]] ''Faserland''.<ref name="NDR"/>
Local myth has it that one can still hear the church bells of Rungholt ringing under the water when sailing through the area on a calm night.<ref name="NDR"/>

{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} '''The Scottish royal tapestry collection''' was a group of [[tapestry]] hangings assembled to decorate the palaces of sixteenth-century kings and queens of [[Scotland]]. ==Tapestry at the Royal Court of Scotland== [[File:WLA metmuseum 1495 Unicorn defend.jpg|thumb|right|400px|Scene from [[The Hunt of the Unicorn]] Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York]] Like other European monarchs, the kings and queens of Scotland sought to impress their subjects and diplomatic visitors in costly surroundings. At [[Fontainebleau]] in 1540, the [[Francis I of France|King of France]] himself personally helped the English ambassador onto a bench so he could examine and admire the 'antique borders' of the tapestry in his bedchamber, and this was seen as a sign of special favour.<ref>''Letters & Papers, Foreign and Domestic of Henry VIII'', vol. 16, no. 276, 17 November 1540.</ref> In Scotland, [[James V of Scotland|James V's]] tapestries were listed in two inventories, along with the crown jewels and fine clothes. These tapestries were used to hang the best chambers and halls in the palaces, and were transported with the monarch between residences and lined, fixed and hung by specialists on the court pay-roll. The rooms were decorated with a painted frieze at the top of the wall and plain beneath where the tapestries hung. [[Henry VIII of England]] had nearly 2000 tapestries and James V had 200.<ref>Thomas, Andrea, ''Princelie Majestie'', John Donald (2005), 79–80 citing Simon Thurley, ''The Royal Palaces of Tudor England'', 222-4.</ref>
Eleven pieces of royal tapestry were destroyed in the explosion at [[Kirk o' Field]] in February 1567 that killed the King Consort of Scotland, [[Henry Stuart, Lord Darnley]].<ref>''Robertson, Joseph, ed., ''Inventaires de la Royne Descosse'', (1863), 51</ref> None of the original Scottish tapestries are known to exist now, but the names of many of them were recorded, and the subjects are the same as those listed in other royal collections,<ref>Buchanan, Iain, The 'Battle of Pavia' and the Tapestry of Don Carlos, ''The Burlington Magazine'', vol. 144, no. 1191, June (2002), 345–351.</ref> and some examples survive in museums around the world. Some of the tapestries showed Biblical themes, or subjects with medieval roots, but most were stories from classical antiquity, reflecting renaissance taste, and some were scenes from the hunting field.
==The reception of Margaret Tudor at Holyroodhouse== In preparation for the arrival of his bride [[Margaret Tudor]] at [[Holyroodhouse]] on 8 August 1503, [[James IV of Scotland]] bought new tapestries. A group was bought from a merchant called James Homyll, who imported textiles from Flanders, which cost £160 Scots. These were a piece with the subject of ''Hercules'', two pieces of ''[[Susanna (Book of Daniel)|Susanna]]'' sewn together, a ''Susanna'' bed cover, a ''Solomon'', and a ''Marcus Coriolanus''. The total measurement which, combined with quality, dictated the price, was 209 square ells. The tapestries were lined with canvas.<ref>''Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland'', vol. 2 (1900), 214.</ref> A set of six verdure tapestries were bought for hanging in the gallery and on the stairs, each costing £3. Five other smaller verdures of various sizes cost £11-4s. Ten fine verdures were bought from John Stewart; three with 'beasts' cost £4-10s each, seven with no beasts cost £4 each. (The 'beasts' may have been unicorns) Four other verdures bought for beds were in quality, 'nocht sa gude,' and cost only 40 shillings each.<ref>''Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland'', vol. 2 (1900), 216, 217.</ref>
Before Margaret left England, the tapestry agent of [[Henry VII of England]], Cornelis van der Strete had been paid £7-8s (English money) for making or supplying 74 Flemish ells of tapestry for the Scottish Consort Queen.<ref>[https://archive.org/details/cu31924091754410 Bain, Joseph, ed., ''Calendar of Documents relating to Scotland'', 1357–1509, vol. 4, HM Register House, Edinburgh (1888), 441, Particular account of Robert Lytton, pp. 319–441]</ref> The historian and curator Thomas P. Campbell suggests these may have been simple armorial tapestries or borders to be attached to figural tapestries purchased elsewhere.<ref>Campbell, Thomas P., ''Henry VIII and the Art of Majesty'', (2007), 91–92, citing a corresponding account, MS PRO TNA E101/415/7, fol. 98.</ref>
The English [[Somerset Herald]], John Young, described some of the tapestry at Holyroodhouse on the two days of celebration. Young noted the hangings in the two outer rooms of the King and Queen's suites where meals were served.<ref>Dunbar, John G., ''Scottish Royal Palaces'', Tuckwell (1999), 132–133.</ref> The Queen's hall was hung with the ''History of Hercules'', and her great chamber with the ''History of Troy Town''. The King's hall was hung with the ''History of Old Troy'', and his great chamber with ''Hercules'' and other stories.<ref>Leland, John ed., ''Collectanea'', vol. 3 (1770), 295–6.</ref> Possibly some of these tapestries were brought to Scotland by Margaret, perhaps with new borders including Tudor heraldry supplied by Cornelis van der Strete.
==Tapestry inventories== Two inventories of 1539 and 1543 list the tapestries of James V.<ref>Harrison, John G., ''Wardrobe Inventories'', Historic Scotland (2008), 9.</ref> Some of these had belonged to James IV, though [[Gavin Douglas]] said that [[John Stewart, Duke of Albany|Regent Albany]] had cut up royal crimson and purple hangings to make clothes for his servants and pages,<ref>Paterson, W., ed., ''The Poetical Works of Gavin Douglas'', vol. 1 (1874), cviii.</ref> but many were bought by James V, or were presents from Francis I. An inventory of September 1561 lists those in Scotland belonging to [[Mary of Guise]], and another compiled on 25 November lists [[Mary, Queen of Scots]]' collection. These lists have notes describing the later locations of the tapestries. Mary Queen of Scots added to the royal collection by confiscating 45 tapestries belonging to the [[George Gordon, 4th Earl of Huntly|Earl of Huntly]] at [[Huntly Castle]] in October 1562. These included one set of large leaf verdures and other set with leaves and birds. Five of the eleven tapestries destroyed at Kirk o'Field were from Huntly, the other were from a suite depicting a "Rabbit Hunt."<ref>Robertson, Joseph, ''Inventaires'', (1863), 51: Thomson (1815), p.157</ref>
After the [[battle of Langside]] in May 1568, the [[James Stewart, 1st Earl of Moray|Regent Moray]] took back from [[Hamilton Palace]] rich silk tapestry and beds that had belonging to James V.<ref>''Calendar State Papers Domestic'', vol.8 (1871), nos. 2230,2232</ref> An inventory of 1578 lists tapestries stored in [[Edinburgh Castle]] and hanging at [[Stirling Castle]] where James VI was resident. Tapestries at Stirling included four pieces of the "Hunts of the Unicorn".<ref>Thomson (1815), 212-3, a second original copy of the 1578 inventory in British Library MS. Harley 4637 has addition notation, including the letter 'S' to indicate items at Stirling.</ref> There may have been royal tapestries elsewhere in Scotland, but the omissions of items and suites listed in the earlier James V inventories raises the possibility that Regent Moray sold tapestries abroad in 1568 along with Mary's pearls, selected royal jewels and a so-called unicorn horn.<ref>Labanoff, A., ''Lettres de Marie Stuart'', vol. 7 (Dolman, London, 1852), 129–134, Bochetel to Charles IX and Catherine de Medici, reports jewel sale, 2–8 May 1568: Nicolas Elphinstone was the agent for jewel sales.</ref> Mary, now a prisoner in England, complained in August 1570 that Scottish ships had brought items of her 'apparel, costly hangings, and jewels' to Hull and other English ports for sale.<ref>''Calendar of State Papers Scotland'', vol.3 (1902), p.289 no.393</ref>
When Mary was moved to [[Tutbury Castle]] in February 1569, three suites of tapestries and carpets were delivered from the Removing Wardrobe at the [[Tower of London]] to furnish her rooms. These included six pieces of the ''Passion'', six pieces of the ''History of Ladies'', and seven pieces of ''Hercules''; the latter two subjects are found in the earlier Scottish inventories.<ref>''Calendar of State Papers Scotland'', vol. 2 (1900), 606.</ref> At [[Sheffield Manor]] in February 1577 she had her own tapestries of ''Aeneas'' and ''Meleager''.<ref>A. Labanoff, ''Lettres de Marie Stuart'', vol.4 (London , 1852), 360; vol.7, 273</ref> In January 1585, when Mary was again being moved to Tutbury, [[Elizabeth I of England|Queen Elizabeth]] recalled that Regent Moray had sent plate, hangings and other items to Mary while she was in the custody of the [[Earl of Shrewsbury]]. The Earl wrote (to [[William Cecil, 1st Baron Burghley|Lord Burghley]]) that this was not the case and Elizabeth was mistaken; 'to my knowledge since her commynge she never received any stuff or other things from him.'<ref>G. Dynfnallt Owen, ed., ''HMC 58, Manuscripts Marquess of Bath'', vol. 5 (London, HMSO, 1980), pp.53–4, 30 January 1584/5.</ref> At Fotheringhay in 1587 she had six pieces of ''Meleager'' and six of the ''Battle of Ravenna'' which she wished to be sold to pay for her servants' journeys home.<ref>A. Labanoff, ''Lettres de Marie Stuart'', vol. 7 (London, 1852), 273</ref>
An inventory of [[Stirling Castle]] made in 1584 records a set of five tapestries hanging in the king's audience chamber, and seven in the bedchamber of the Palace.<ref>HMC, ''9th report & appendix, part 2, Lord Elphinstone'', (1884), 193.</ref> Some of the tapestries were at [[Dunfermline Palace]] in 1616, where [[Alexander Seton, 1st Earl of Dunfermline]], had looked after the infant [[Charles I of England|Prince Charles]].<ref>''Register of the Privy Council of Scotland'', vol. 10 (1891), 521.</ref> Among the remaining contents of the Royal Wardrobe at Holyroodhouse in 1617, three pieces of green velvet embroidered with gold holly leaves and the [[Duc de Longueville|Longueville]] arms, which had belonged to Mary of Guise (Duchess of Longueville by her first marriage), were sent for repair.<ref>''Register of the Privy Council of Scotland'', vol. xi, (1894), 37.</ref> In 1635, Charles I wrote to [[John Stewart, 1st Earl of Traquair]], [[Lord High Treasurer of Scotland|Treasurer of Scotland]], insisting on the payment of the wardrobe servants, so that hangings, cloths-of-estate, and beds could be aired.<ref>Historical Manuscript Commission, ''9th Report & Appendix, Traquair House'', (1884), 246b.</ref> The remaining tapestries at Holyrood would have been seized by [[Commonwealth of England|Commonwealth]] troops in 1650. In April 1656, soldiers retrieved and sent to Whitehall four pieces of the ''Labours of Hercules'', perhaps the latest mention of tapestry from the Scottish royal collection.<ref>Thomson, W.G., ''A History of Tapestry'', Hodder & Stoughton (1930), 359–370, citing ''CSP Domestic'', 1655–1656, 23, 315.</ref>
===Bought in Paris=== The six pieces of the ''Triumphant Dames'' or ''City of Dames'' were bought in Paris in 1537 or 1538 for 883 francs 10 sous during James V's trip to marry [[Madeleine of Valois]]. The pieces varied slightly in size with a total area of 147 square [[ell]]s, each square ell costed at six francs. These were sent to [[Rouen]] by boat and then to [[Le Havre|Newhaven]] in France for shipping, along with another set called the ''Old and New Stories''. A set with a similar name, the ''New Law and the Old'', was listed among [[Catherine of Aragon]]'s effects in February 1536.<ref>''Letters & Papers Henry VIII'', vol. 8, (1885), no. 209, she also had a ''Jason'' and a ''Hercules''.</ref> The Scottish suite was probably the ten-piece ''Old Testament'' listed in the inventory of 1539. Only one piece was noted in 1542, and none was heard of again in Scotland.<ref>''Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland'', ''TA'', vol. 7, (1907), 28, 39, 43–4: [[Thomas Thomson (advocate)|Thomson, Thomas]], ''A Collection of Royal Inventories'', Bannatyne Club, (1815), 49, 103.</ref> James V's servant George Steill was sent to Flanders from Paris on 3 February 1537 to acquire more tapestries. At the same time James V hired a new French tapestry-man, William, and gave him 20 crowns to bring his wife and children to Scotland.<ref>''Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland'', vol. 7 (1907), 17, 18, 44.</ref>
Years later, when Mary, Queen of Scots, was a prisoner at [[Tutbury Castle]], six pieces of series called the ''History of Ladies'' were sent from the Tower of London.<ref>''Calendar State Papers Scotland'', vol. 2, 606.</ref> This was probably one of three sets of the ''City of Ladies'' that had belonged to Henry VIII, listed in the [[Inventory of Henry VIII of England|inventory of 1547]], which were identical in size piece by piece to the Scottish tapestries. These had decorated the childhood homes of [[Elizabeth I of England|Princess Elizabeth]] and [[Edward VI of England|Prince Edward]]<ref>Starkey, David, ''Inventory of Henry VIII'', vol.1, Harvey Millar (1998), nos. 9021, 14033, 15272. (sq-yard:sq-Fr. ell ratio 1:1.6, sq Fr. ell:sq Fl. ell ratio 1:3.)</ref> The subject derives from [[Christine de Pizan]]'s ''[[The Book of the City of Ladies]].''<ref>Hindman, Sandra L., ''Feminist Studies'', vol. 10, no. 3, Autumn (1984), 459–483.</ref> Other sets of the subject belonged to [[Margaret of Austria, Duchess of Savoy|Margaret of Austria]], [[Mary of Austria, Queen of Hungary|Mary of Hungary]], [[Anne of Brittany]] and Francis I.<ref>Bell, Susan Groag, ''The Lost Tapestries of the City of Ladies'', (2004), 167–8.</ref>
The other tapestry bought in Paris and packed for shipping to Rouen was the ''Creation of World'', of which nine pieces were at [[Holyroodhouse]] in 1561, and in Edinburgh Castle in 1578.<ref>''Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland'', vol. 7 (1907), 44: Thomson (1815), 126, no. 19, 211: ''Inventaires de la Royne d'Ecosse'', 20, no. 19.</ref> In 1616, Alexander Seton had some 'auld and worne' pieces described as the ''Storie of Mankynd'' at Dunfermline Palace.<ref>''Register of the Privy Council of Scotland'', vol. 10, (1891), 521.</ref> The set could possibly have been ''The World'' series, depicting various moral allegories and including a globe.<ref>Adelson, Candace J., ''European Tapestry in the Minneapolis Institute of Arts'', (1994), 92–104.</ref> A list of wedding gifts from Francis I adds four suites of rich arras hangings, and eight suites of coarser arras, all 'ret verey good.'<ref>[[William Guthrie (historian)|Guthrie, William]], ''History of Scotland'', vol. 5, London (1767), 166 citing Balfour's annals: [https://books.google.com/books?id=Q10LAAAAYAAJ&source=gbs_navlinks_s ''The Historical works of Sir James Balfour'', vol. 1, Edinburgh (1824), 266–267]</ref> These gifts would have been included among the tapestries named in the Scottish inventories mentioned below. In October 1546, an [[Antwerp]] merchant, Eustatius de Coqueil, wrote to Mary of Guise offering her histories and other tapestries, but it seems unlikely that any were bought during this brief period of peace in the [[war of the Rough Wooing]].<ref>Wood, Marguerite, ''Balcarres Papers'', vol. 1, SHS (1923), 148–9.</ref>
===Tobias and the Angel and the Tint Barne=== The ''Tint Barne'', the ''History of the Lost Child'', might appear to be the same subject as the ''History of Tobias''. However the five-piece ''Tobias'' was listed in 1539 and also in 1542, along with the seven-piece ''Tint Barne''.<ref>Thomson (1815), 49, 103</ref> The subject of the ''tinte barne'' was probably the ''[[Prodigal Son]]'', a subject listed many times in the inventory of Henry VIII,<ref>Starkey, David, ''The Inventory of Henry VIII'', vol. 1, Harvey Millar (1998), nos. 9283, 9288, 9737, 11996-9, 1258–71, 13342, 14049.</ref> and [[Cardinal Wolsey]] had seven pieces.<ref>Verdier, Philippe, 'The Tapestry of the Prodigal Son', ''The Journal of The Walters Art Gallery'', vol. 18 (1955), 46.</ref>
===Chamber of the Antique history=== These were delivered by a William Schaw in 1539, costing 2466 crowns of the sun (French – ''ecu d'or au soleil''). It was a group of five (or six) sets of seven pieces, and included seven ''Sundry pieces histories of Chambers'' in fine stuff listed in 1539. Additions for this ''Chamber of Antique History'' were bought by a servant of John Moffet, conservator of Flanders in April 1541.<ref>''TA'', vii, (1907), 253, 257, 278, 290, 471: Thomson (1815), 51.</ref> The word 'chamber' referred to the suite of tapestry rather than any actual room in the palaces. Subjects supplied by William Schaw listed in 1539 include; seven pieces of ''Poesy''; seven pieces of ''Jason and Golden Fleece''; and seven pieces of ''[[Venus (mythology)|Venus]]'', ''[[Athena|Pallas]]'', ''[[Hercules]]'', ''[[Mars (mythology)|Mars]]'', ''[[Bacchus]]'', and ''[[Gaia (mythology)|Gaia]]'' (''Mother of the Earth''), with the Biblical ''History of Solomon''. Only six pieces of the ''Jason'' were listed in 1542. Four pieces of the ''Solomon'' were listed in September 1561, and noted circa 1568 to be at Stirling. The others are not heard of again. The ''Little Solomon'' was also noted in September 1561, another set, or perhaps three of the seven scenes pieces bought by William Schaw.
The seven-piece ''History of Perseus'' was presumably of this group, though not linked in the inventories of 1539 and 1540 to William Schaw's purchase. [[James IV of Scotland|James IV]] had bought one piece of a ''History of Hercules'', and nine were listed in 1542. This was a suite separate to the ''Hercules'' in the ancient god series of the ''Chambers''.<ref>Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland'', vol. 2 , 214, June 1503 : Thomson (1815), 103.</ref>
Similarly a three piece ''History of Romulus'' was listed in 1542. The ''Old History of Troy'' of eight or nine pieces listed in 1539 and 1542 was perhaps a Stewart inheritance, old and already described as worn out, so distinguished from the ''Aeneas''. The family of Mary of Guise's first husband, Louis II d'Orléans, [[Duc de Longueville]], had ''Troy'' tapestries at their [[Château de Châteaudun]] as early as 1468.<ref>McKendrick, Scot, The Great History of Troy, ''Journal of the Warburg & Courtauld Institutes'', vol. 54, (1991), 56.</ref>
The 13 pieces of the ''History of Aeneas'' were carried from Edinburgh Castle to [[St. Andrews]] in May 1539, and are listed in the inventory of 1539.<ref>''Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland'', vol. 7, 165: Thomson, (1815), 49.</ref> Eight pieces described as the ''Sailing of Aeneas'' are listed in November 1561 at Holyroodhouse, with a note, presumably of c.1568, locating them at Stirling Castle.<ref>Thomson, (1815), 143: ''Inventaires de la Royne d'Ecosse'', Bannatyne Club (1863), 39 (no. 87).</ref> In 1578 there were eight ''Sailing'' pieces and four others at Edinburgh Castle.<ref>Thomson, (1815), 211.</ref> The extra tapestry may have been a piece from the ''Old History of Troy,'' or possibly the ''Sailing of Aeneas'' set, first listed in November 1561, was newly brought from France by Queen Mary and not part of James's ''Aeneas''. Alexander Seton had some of the ''Aeneas'' and ''Troy'' at Dunfermline among his 10 old pieces in 1616.<ref>''Register of the Privy Council of Scotland'', vol. 7, 37.</ref> An area of the garden of Holyroodhouse was called the ''Sege of Troy'', and there may have been a connection, perhaps only that the tapestries were aired there.<ref>''Register of the Great Seal of Scotland,'' 1580–1593, (1888), 142, no. 456.</ref>
===The Meleager=== A separate subject from the ''Jason'', listed in 1539 as the ''History of Maliasor'', this six-piece tapestry of ''[[Meleager]]'' was at [[Fotheringhay Castle]] in 1587 as Mary's own possession. At Fotheringay, Mary, Queen of Scots, also had the six pieces of the ''History of Count Foix and the Battle of Ravenna'', from the Scottish collection,<ref>Bath, Michael, ''Emblems for a Queen'', Archetype (2008), 6.</ref> but as this set was only previously listed in November 1561 it might not have belonged to her parents. An eighteenth-century engraving of Gaston de Foix was said to derive from a similar tapestry.[[File:Gaston de Foix (engraving).jpg|thumb|Gaston de Foix, from a tapestry]] [[Amias Paulet]] her gaoler spent £113-10s in English money on lining, packing, and hanging eight pieces of her tapestry during her move from [[Chartley Castle|Chartley]] to [[Fotheringhay Castle]].<ref>''Accounts and Papers relating to Mary Queen of Scots'', Camden Society, p.22.</ref> Mary wished the ''Meleager'' and ''Ravenna'' to be sold after her death, with cloths-of-estate, to fund the return journeys of her physician and Mr Melville.<ref>Thomson (1815), 49: Labanoff, A., ''Lettres de Marie-Stuart'', vol. 7, Dolman (1852), 236, 273–4.</ref> Like the ''Meleager'', the biblical ''Roboam'' which appears in most inventories also dates from 1539.
===Triumph and Assault of a Town=== This may have been a copy of the famous tapestry commissioned by [[Francis I of France|François Ier]] from designs by [[Giulio Romano]], the ''Gestes of Scipion'', the story of [[Scipio Africanus]], which includes the scene ''Siege of Carthagena''. However, like the ''Battle of Ravenna'', the five pieces are first listed in November 1561 and so this too might not have belonged to James and Mary of Guise, unless they were among the unspecified tapestries bought by William Schaw in 1539.<ref>''Inventaires'', (1863), 39 no. 81: Thomson (1815), 144 no. 81.</ref> However, there are other tapestries with the subject ''Siege of a Town'' in late medieval style which answer the description. Another possibility is that these were scenes of the ''Siege of Troy'', a subject found in Henry VIII's collection.<ref>Starkey, David, The ''Inventory of Henry VIII'', (1998), Troy nos. 12621, 14034; Siege of Troy no. 13053.</ref> Possibly, this tapestry was in mind when Mary of Guise, according to [[John Knox]], remarked that the aftermath of the failed assault on [[Siege of Leith|Leith]] of 7 May 1560 was the fairest tapestry she had ever seen.<ref>Knox, John, ''History of the Reformation'', Book 2.</ref>
===Unicorns, apes, beasts and others=== [[File:Replica Unicorn tapestry, Stirling Castle.JPG|thumb|Unicorn tapestry woven in 2010, in Mary of Guise's Audience Chamber at [[Stirling Castle]]]] James V's other named tapestries included the six Great and eight Little ''[[Unicorn]]'' pieces. The ''Great Unicorn'' set has been identified as another version of the famous tapestries, the [[The Hunt of the Unicorn|Hunt of the Unicorn]], now in the [[The Cloisters|Cloisters]] Museum of the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in New York. Faithful copies using the original technique are being made for display in the Palace of Stirling Castle. These unicorn tapestries had belonged to his father, James IV, but the subject was still popular in 1540, when Pierre de Clanquemeulle, companion tapestry maker, was hired by Léon Brocart, master weaver in Paris, to complete two pieces of an ''Histoire de la Chasse à la licorne''.<ref>Grodecki, Cathérine, ''Documents du Minutier Central des Notaires de Paris: Histoire de l'art au XVIe siècle, 1540–1600'', vol. 1, Archives Nationales, (1984), 279.</ref>
Seven pieces of the ''History of the Apis and uther Bestis'' were recorded in 1539. Six pieces of the History of Apes were recorded in 1561. In January 1563 three pieces of this tapestry with monkeys, the ''tapisserie des singes'', were given by Mary Queen of Scots to Pierre Marnard the court ''fruictier'', a kitchen officer who took part in masques.<ref>J. Robertson, ''Inventaires'', (1863), 137: T. Thomson, ''Collection of Inventories'', 50, 127</ref>
Listed in the September 1561 inventory, 10 pieces of ''History of Hunting and Hawking'' may have been a separate item originally belonging to James V, and perhaps distinct from the six-piece set of the ''Hunting of the Sanglier'' (Wild Boar), and seven-piece ''Coningars'' (the Rabbit Hunt), listed in later inventories. One scene from this ''Rabbit Hunt'', otherwise called the ''L’histoire des Chasseurs de Cogny'' in an inventory written in French, was said to have been lost at [[Linlithgow Palace|Linlithgow]] during the 1566 baptism of [[James VI of Scotland|James VI]] at Stirling. However this loss had already been recorded in 1565, as having occurred at Linlithgow during the keepership of [[James Sandilands, 1st Lord Torphichen|James Sandilands]], Master of the [[Torphichen Preceptory|Preceptory of St John at Torphichen]], perhaps the one later said to have been cut by "Andro Cockburn fule." The other six pieces were destroyed at the Kirk o'Field explosion. Another tapestry of the "Rabbit Hunt" had been made into bed curtains.<ref>j. Robertson, ''Inventaires'', (1863), 51, 153, 178, 20 May 1567: Thomson (1815), 142, 157.</ref> The [[Burrell Collection]] in Glasgow has an example of a tapestry of this subject, dated from c. 1475.<ref>''The Burrell Collection'', Collins, (1983), 105.</ref>
James IV bought one scene of [[Gaius Marcius Coriolanus|''Marcus Coriolanus'']], which may be the ''Mathiolus'' tapestry mentioned in later inventories, and a ''Solomon'', which may be ''Judgement of Solomon'' noted in September 1561, of worsett with gold.<ref>''Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland'', vol. 2, 214.</ref> Alternatively, Susan Groag Bell wonders if this ''Mathiolus'' was the first scene of the ''City of Ladies'' suite bought in 1538, featuring the name of the author [[Mathieu of Boulogne|Matheolus]] as a protagonist illustrating the works of [[Christine de Pisan]].<ref>Bell, Susan Groag, ''The Lost Tapestries of the City of Ladies'', University of California, (2004), 21–22, 133.</ref>
The subject of the ''History of the Shepherds'' of seven pieces and the ''History of Calveris and Moris'' of four pieces noted in 1561 may be obscure. The eight-piece ''Triumph of Verity'' also noted in November 1561 may have come to Scotland with Mary in 1561, unless perhaps this was yet another name for the ''City of Dames.''
===The tapestry men=== When James V moved around Scotland the ''tapissiers'' or 'tapestry men' packed up the tapestries and set them up at his destination, and carried out running repairs. George Steill bound up twelve scenes of the ''History of Aeneas'' with cords and carried them from Edinburgh to St Andrews in May 1539 for the marriage of Joanna Gresmore to the Laird of Creich.<ref>''Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer'', vol. 7, 165.</ref> Eight pieces of tapestry were specially repaired for the coronation of Mary of Guise in January 1540, and others were often relined with new canvas.<ref>''Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland'', vol. 7 (1907), 94, 294.</ref> Jacques Habet, William Edbe and George Steill lined the rough or newly plastered walls of the castle at [[Crawfordjohn]] to save wear on tapestries in July 1541.<ref>''Accounts of Lord Treasurer of Scotland,'' vol. 7 (1907), 458.</ref> Apart from this work, the men also made up and embroidered state beds with luxury imported silks and taffetas with hanks of gold thread, finished with [[passementerie]] and ostrich feather trimmings.<ref>''Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland'', vol. 7 (1907), 411–412.</ref> Guillaume, hired in France in 1538, Habet, and the embroiderer Robinet, were doubtless Frenchmen, but William Edbe was Scottish.<ref>Thomas, Andrea, ''Princelie Majestie'', John Donald, (2005), 79: ''TA'', vol. 7, 44.</ref> Habet may have been the "Jacques Hebert" later hired by the Parisian master weaver Girard Laurens in 1564.<ref>Grodecki,Cathérine, ''Documents du Minutier Central des Notaires de Paris: Histoire de l'Art au XVIe siècle, 1540–1600'', vol. 1, Archives Nationales, (1985), 301 no.436</ref>
There was extra work when the tapestry was taken out of the castles and used on other occasions. In May 1544, when an [[Burning of Edinburgh (1544)|English army burnt Edinburgh]], the tapestries were carried up the [[Royal Mile]] from Holyroodhouse to the Castle for safety and watched by Regent Arran's wardrobe servant Malcolm Gourlay.<ref>[https://archive.org/details/accountslordhig00unkngoog ''Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland'', vol.8, HM General Register House (1908)] lv–lix, pp.276, 289–291.</ref> [[Regent Arran]] borrowed the royal tapestry for his daughter Barbara's wedding in 1549, and after it had been cleaned by six apprentices it was brought out for the visit of Mary of Guise's brother, the [[Claude, Duke of Aumale|Marquis de Maine]].<ref>''Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland'', vol. 7 (1907), 94, 294, 458.</ref> In April 1569, tapestry was hung in Glasgow for the French ambassador, in April 1572 the Deanery at [[Restalrig]] was hung with tapestry for the English ambassadors [[Thomas Randolph (diplomat)|Thomas Randolph]] and [[William Drury]], and in September 1572, William Murray, the [[Valet de chambre|varlet]] of [[James VI of Scotland|James VI]]'s bedchamber hung the tollbooth of Stirling with tapestry.<ref>''Accounts of the Lord Treasurer of Scotland'', vol. 12 (1970), 119, 282: T. Thomson, ed., ''Diurnal of Occurrents'', (Edinburgh, 1833), 291</ref> George Strathauchin, embroiderer, was James's "tapiser" with annual salary of £40 and lodging; on 7 October 1584, the [[Patrick Gray, 6th Lord Gray|Master of Gray]] was made Keeper of the Wardrobe, including the tapestry, with all officers of the household commanded to reverence, acknowledge and obey him.<ref>''Register of the Privy Seal of Scotland'', vol. 8 (1982), 132, no. 800; 436, no. 2486.</ref>

{{italic title}} The '''''South American Handbook''''' is a travel guide to [[South America]], published in the United Kingdom by [[Footprint Travel Guides|Footprint Books]]. It is the longest-running travel guide in the English language. In 2010 it was chosen as the Best South American Handbook by ''Sounds and Colours''.<ref>[http://www.soundsandcolours.com/the-best/the-best-books/the-best-south-american-travel-guidebooks/ The Best South American Travel Guidebooks]</ref>
==History== The handbook was first published in 1921 as the ''Anglo-South American Handbook''. It was founded and compiled by [[William Henry Koebel]] (1872-1923),<ref>[https://openlibrary.org/authors/OL18500A/W._H._Koebel Open Library: W. H. Koebel]</ref> a prolific author who had a particular interest in promoting trade with South America. It was compiled as a guide to South America, as well as Mexico and Cuba, for the business traveller, and published by the [[Federation of British Industry]].<ref>Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, ''Koebel, William Henry''</ref>
Two editions later the book was 'privatised' and in 1924 it became the ''South American Handbook'', published by Trade and Travel Publications Ltd, a [[Royal Mail Steam Packet Company]] subsidiary<ref name=Nicol>{{cite book |last=Nicol |first=Stuart |year=2001 |title=MacQueen's Legacy; A History of the Royal Mail Line |volume=One |place=Brimscombe Port and Charleston, SC |publisher=[[The History Press|Tempus Publishing]] |isbn=0-7524-2118-2 |page=17}}</ref> incorporated in December 1922.<ref name=coho>[http://wck2.companieshouse.gov.uk Companies House Webcheck] Company number 186564</ref> At the time, travel was by sea and the handbook gave all the details needed for the long voyage from Europe, including a full account of the journey from Liverpool up the [[Amazon River|Amazon]] to [[Manaus]], some 5,898 miles without changing cabin. It also imparted such invaluable etiquette advice as to 'pack a good saddle and a set of starched collars'.
From about the 1930s the Mendip Press of [[Bath, Somerset]] printed the book. Early in the 1970s Royal Mail Lines sold Trade and Travel Publications to the Mendip Press's parent company, Dawson and Goodall Ltd.<ref name=Nicol/> The handbook continued to be published annually and received updates from readers, including figures such as [[Paul Theroux]] and the novelist [[Graham Greene]], who addressed his updates to 'The publishers of the best travel guide in the world, Bath, England'.
Over the years the handbook expanded its coverage to include all the countries of South America, Central America, Mexico and the Caribbean. It continued to include data for businessmen, but by the 1970s was increasingly aimed at leisure travellers, particularly backpackers following the [[Gringo Trail]]. In 1989 the 65th edition was almost 1,400 pages long.
In 1990 the handbook was split. The ''Mexico & Central America Handbook'' and the ''Caribbean Islands Handbook'' were published as separate volumes, and from then on the ''South American Handbook'' covered only South America.
Trade and Travel Publications changed its name to Footprint Handbooks Ltd in August 1996.<ref name=coho/>
== The ''Handbook'' today == The ''South American Handbook'' 2018 (94th edition) contains 1,824 pages.<ref>{{cite book|title=South American Handbook|isbn=978 1911082231}}</ref> It is edited by Ben Box, who has written for the handbook since 1980, as editor since 1989.

{{notability|date=October 2018}} {{unreferenced|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox Journal |title = St. Nersess Theological Review |abbreviation = St. Nersess Theol. Rev. |cover = St-nersess-theological-review.jpg |editor = Abraham Terian
Roberta R. Ervine |discipline = [[Armenian studies]] |language = [[English language|English]] (abstracts) |website = https://www.stnersess.edu/st-nersess-theological-review.html |link1 = |link1-name = |publisher = [[St. Nersess Armenian Seminary]] |country = [[United States]] |frequency = [[Annual publication|Annually]] (varying frequency) |history = 1996 – Present |ISSN = 1086-2080 |JSTOR = }} The '''St. Nersess Theological Review''' (abbreviated as '''SNTR''') is an [[Armenology|Armenological]] publication established in 1996 by [[St. Nersess Armenian Seminary]] (150 Stratton Rd, New Rochelle, NY 10804) and published semi-annually[https://naasr.org/products/st-nerses-theological-review National Association for Armenian Studies and Research (NAASR): ''St. Nersess Theological Review''] (at times annually or with varying frequency). The founding editor was Abraham Terian who ran the journal for many years. Presently, the journal is edited by Roberta R. Ervine. SNTR publishes articles about [[Christianity]] in the [[Armenian Church]]; e.g. theology, liturgy, philosophy, ethics, biblical studies, canon law, church history, ecumenics, literature, fine arts, archaeology, and interdisciplinary studies, as well as translations of Armenian patristic texts. It also publishes short notes, review articles and book reviews in all fields related to the Armenian Church. ==External links== *[https://www.stnersess.edu/st-nersess-theological-review.html St. Nersess Theological Review page] [[Category:Armenian studies]] [[Category:Publications established in 1996]] [[Category:Christianity studies journals]]
